Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Births
txt: Giacomo Puccini, Italian composer and educator (d. 1924)

entities.title: Giacomo Puccini
entities.description: Giacomo Puccini was an Italian composer known primarily for his operas. Regarded as the greatest and most successful proponent of Italian opera after Verdi, he was descended from a long line of composers, stemming to the late-Baroque era. Though his early work was firmly rooted in traditional late-19th-century Romantic Italian opera he later developed his work in the realistic verismo style, of wh

heading: Births
txt: Connie Mack, American baseball player and manager (d. 1956)

entities.title: Connie Mack
entities.description: Cornelius McGillicuddy, better known as Connie Mack, was an American professional baseball catcher, manager, and team owner. The longest-serving manager in Major League Baseball history, he holds records for wins (3,731), losses (3,948), and games managed (7,755), with his victory total being almost 1,000 more than any other manager.

heading: Births
txt: Charles Sands, American golfer and tennis player (d. 1945)

entities.title: Charles Sands
entities.description: Charles Edward Sands was an American golfer, tennis and real tennis player who competed in the 1900 Summer Olympics and in the 1908 Summer Olympics.

heading: Births
txt: Jaan Tõnisson, Estonian journalist, lawyer, and politician, 2nd Prime Minister of Estonia (d. 1941?)

entities.title: Jaan Tõnisson
entities.description: Jaan Tõnisson was an Estonian statesman, serving as the Prime Minister of Estonia twice during 1919 to 1920, as State Elder from 1927 to 1928 and in 1933, and as Foreign Minister of Estonia from 1931 to 1932.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Estonia
entities.description: The Prime Minister of Estonia is the head of government of the Republic of Estonia. The prime minister is nominated by the President after appropriate consultations with the parliamentary factions and confirmed by the Parliament. In case of disagreement, the Parliament can reject the President's nomination and choose their own candidate. In practice, since the Prime Minister must maintain the conf

heading: Births
txt: Dmitri Egorov, Russian mathematician and academic (d. 1931)

entities.title: Dmitri Egorov
entities.description: Dmitri Fyodorovich Egorov was a Russian and Soviet mathematician known for contributions to the areas of differential geometry and mathematical analysis. He was President of the Moscow Mathematical Society (1923–1930).

heading: Births
txt: Edwin Arlington Robinson, American poet and playwright (d. 1935)

heading: Births
txt: Camille Guérin, French veterinarian and bacteriologist (d. 1961)

entities.title: Camille Guérin
entities.description: Jean-Marie Camille Guérin was a French veterinarian, bacteriologist and immunologist who, together with Albert Calmette, developed the Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG), a vaccine for immunization against tuberculosis.

heading: Births
txt: Franz Schmidt, Austrian cellist, pianist, and composer (d. 1939)

entities.title: Franz Schmidt
entities.description: Franz Schmidt, also Ferenc Schmidt was an Austro-Hungarian composer, cellist and pianist.

heading: Births
txt: Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, Egyptian-Italian poet and composer (d. 1944)

entities.title: Filippo Tommaso Marinetti
entities.description: Filippo Tommaso Emilio Marinetti was an Italian poet, editor, art theorist, and founder of the Futurist movement. He was associated with the utopian and Symbolist artistic and literary community Abbaye de Créteil between 1907 and 1908. Marinetti is best known as the author of the first Futurist Manifesto, which was written and published in 1909.

heading: Births
txt: Myer Prinstein, Polish-American jumper (d. 1925)

entities.title: Myer Prinstein
entities.description: Myer Prinstein was a Polish American track and field athlete and member of the Irish American Athletic Club. He held the world record for the long jump and won gold medals in three Olympic Games for the long jump and triple jump.

heading: Births
txt: Marcus Hurley, American cyclist (d. 1941)

entities.title: Marcus Hurley
entities.description: Marcus Latimer Hurley was an American cyclist who competed in the early twentieth century. He specialized in sprint cycling and won 4 gold medals in Cycling at the 1904 Summer Olympics and a bronze medal in the 2 mile race.

heading: Births
txt: Edgard Varèse, French-American composer (d. 1965)

heading: Births
txt: St. Elmo Brady, African American chemist and educator (d. 1966)

entities.title: St. Elmo Brady
entities.description: Saint Elmo Brady was the first African American to obtain a Ph.D. degree in chemistry in the United States. He received his doctorate at the University of Illinois in 1916.

heading: Births
txt: Deems Taylor, American conductor and critic (d. 1966)

entities.title: Deems Taylor
entities.description: Joseph Deems Taylor was an American music critic, composer, and promoter of classical music. Nat Benchley, co-editor of The Lost Algonquin Roundtable, referred to him as "the dean of American music."

heading: Births
txt: Srinivasa Ramanujan, Indian mathematician and theorist (d. 1920)

entities.title: Srinivasa Ramanujan
entities.description: Srinivasa Ramanujan was an Indian mathematician who lived during the British Rule in India. Though he had almost no formal training in pure mathematics, he made substantial contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions, including solutions to mathematical problems then considered unsolvable. Ramanujan initially developed his own mathematical resear

heading: Births
txt: J. Arthur Rank, 1st Baron Rank, English businessman, founded Rank Organisation (d. 1972)

entities.title: J. Arthur Rank, 1st Baron Rank
entities.description: Joseph Arthur Rank, 1st Baron Rank was a British industrialist who was head and founder of the Rank Organisation.

entities.title: Rank Organisation
entities.description: The Rank Organisation was a British entertainment conglomerate founded by industrialist J. Arthur Rank in April 1937. It quickly became the largest and most vertically integrated film company in the United Kingdom, owning production, distribution and exhibition facilities. It also diversified into the manufacture of radios, TVs and photocopiers. The company name lasted until February 1996, when th

heading: Births
txt: George Hutson, English runner and soldier (d. 1914)

entities.title: George Hutson
entities.description: George William Hutson was a British athlete who competed mainly in long-distance running events. He was born in Lewes, East Sussex.

heading: Births
txt: Herman Potočnik, Croatian-Austrian engineer (d. 1929)

entities.title: Herman Potočnik
entities.description: Herman Potočnik was a Slovene rocket engineer and pioneer of astronautics. He is chiefly remembered for his work addressing the long-term human habitation of space.

heading: Births
txt: Vladimir Fock, Russian physicist and mathematician (d. 1974)

entities.title: Vladimir Fock
entities.description: Vladimir Aleksandrovich Fock was a Soviet physicist, who did foundational work on quantum mechanics and quantum electrodynamics.

heading: Births
txt: Gustaf Gründgens, German actor and director (d. 1963)

entities.title: Gustaf Gründgens
entities.description: Gustaf Gründgens, born Gustav Heinrich Arnold Gründgens, was one of Germany's most famous and influential actors of the 20th century, and artistic director of theatres in Berlin, Düsseldorf, and Hamburg. His career continued unimpeded through the years of the Nazi regime; the extent to which this can be considered as deliberate collaboration with the Nazis is hotly disputed.

heading: Births
txt: Marc Allégret, French director and screenwriter (d. 1973)

entities.title: Marc Allégret
entities.description: Marc Allégret was a French screenwriter, photographer and film director.

heading: Births

entities.title: Andre Kostelanetz
entities.description: Andre Kostelanetz was a Russian-born American popular orchestral music conductor and arranger who was one of the major exponents of popular orchestra music.

entities.title: Haldan Keffer Hartline
entities.description: Haldan Keffer Hartline was an American physiologist who was a co-recipient of the 1967 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work in analyzing the neurophysiological mechanisms of vision.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

entities.title: Giacomo Manzù
entities.description: Giacomo Manzù, pseudonym of Giacomo Manzoni, was an Italian sculptor.

entities.description: The first lady of the United States is the hostess of the White House. The position is traditionally filled by the wife of the president of the United States, but, on occasion, the title has been applied to women who were not presidents’ wives, such as when the president was a bachelor or widower, or when the wife of the president was unable to fulfill the duties of the first lady. heading: Births
txt: Giorgio Oberweger, Italian discus thrower and hurdler (d. 1998)

entities.title: Giorgio Oberweger
entities.description: Giorgio Oberweger was an Italian discus thrower who won a bronze medal at the 1936 Olympics and a silver at the 1938 European Champsionships. He placed sixth at the 1934 European Championships and 15th at the 1948 Olympics. Oberweger won five national titles, in the discus throw and 110 metres hurdles (1939).

heading: Births

entities.title: Barbara Billingsley
entities.description: Barbara Billingsley was an American film, television, voice, and stage actress. She began her career with uncredited roles in Three Guys Named Mike (1951), The Bad and the Beautiful (1952), and Invaders from Mars (1953), and was featured in the 1957 movie The Careless Years, opposite Natalie Trundy before appearing in recurring TV roles such as The Brothers.

entities.description: Sir Peregrine Gerard Worsthorne was a British journalist, writer, and broadcaster. He spent the largest part of his career at the Telegraph newspaper titles, eventually becoming editor of The Sunday Telegraph for several years. He left the newspaper in 1997.

txt: Frank Corsaro, American actor and director (d. 2017)

entities.title: Frank Corsaro
entities.description: Frank Corsaro was one of America's foremost stage directors of opera and theatre. His Broadway productions include The Night of the Iguana (1961).

He was a professor in the Department of Anthropology at Boston University, and previously held professorships at the University of Oslo, the University of Bergen, Emory University and Harvard University. He was appointed a government scholar in 1985.

entities.description: Phillip Abraham Woosnam was a Welsh association football inside-right and manager. He was described as a "gifted inside-forward with a pronounced football intelligence".

entities.description: Olav Magnusson was king of Norway in 1103–1115. He was the son of King Magnus Barefoot and Sigrid, daughter of Saxe of Vik.

txt: Antipope John XXIII

entities.title: Antipope John XXIII
entities.description: Baldassarre Cossa was Pisan antipope John XXIII (1410–1415) during the Western Schism. The Catholic Church regards him as an antipope, as he opposed Pope Gregory XII whom the Catholic Church now recognizes as the rightful successor of Saint Peter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Willibald Pirckheimer, German lawyer and author (b. 1470)

entities.title: Willibald Pirckheimer
entities.description: Willibald Pirckheimer was a German Renaissance lawyer, author and Renaissance humanist, a wealthy and prominent figure in Nuremberg in the 16th century, and a member of the governing City Council for two periods. He was the closest friend of the artist Albrecht Dürer, who made a number of portraits of him, and a close friend of the great humanist and theologian Erasmus.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alessandro Bonvicino, Italian painter (b. 1498)

entities.title: Alessandro Bonvicino
entities.description: Alessandro Bonvicino, more commonly known as Moretto, or in Italian Il Moretto da Brescia, was an Italian Renaissance painter from Brescia, where he also mostly worked. His dated works span the period from 1524 to 1554, but he was already described as a master in 1516. He was mainly a painter of altarpieces that tend towards sedateness, mostly for churches in and around Brescia, but also in Bergam

heading: Deaths
txt: François Clouet, French miniaturist (b. c. 1510)

entities.title: François Clouet
entities.description: François Clouet, son of Jean Clouet, was a French Renaissance miniaturist and painter, particularly known for his detailed portraits of the French ruling family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mehmed III, Ottoman sultan (b. 1566)

entities.title: Mehmed III
entities.description: Mehmed III was Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1595 until his death in 1603.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maximilien de Béthune, Duke of Sully, 2nd Prime Minister of France (b. 1560)

entities.title: Maximilien de Béthune, Duke of Sully
entities.description: Maximilien de Béthune, 1st Duke of Sully, Marquis of Rosny and Nogent, Count of Muret and Villebon, Viscount of Meaux was a nobleman, soldier, statesman, and counselor of King Henry IV of France. Historians emphasize Sully's role in building a strong centralized administrative system in France using coercion and highly effective new administrative techniques. While not all of his policies were ori

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

heading: Deaths
txt: Petro Mohyla, Ruthenian metropolitan and saint (b. 1596)

entities.title: Petro Mohyla
entities.description: Metropolitan Peter was an influential Ruthenian Orthodox theologian and reformer, Metropolitan of Kyiv, Halych and All Rus' from 1633 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: André Tacquet, Flemish priest and mathematician (b. 1612)

entities.title: André Tacquet
entities.description: André Tacquet was a Brabantian mathematician and Jesuit priest. Tacquet adhered to the methods of the geometry of Euclid and the philosophy of Aristotle and opposed the method of indivisibles.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guercino, Italian painter (b. 1591)

entities.title: Guercino
entities.description: Giovanni Francesco Barbieri, better known as Guercino, or il Guercino [ɡwerˈtʃiːno], was an Italian Baroque painter and draftsman from Cento in the Emilia region, who was active in Rome and Bologna. The vigorous naturalism of his early manner contrasts with the classical equilibrium of his later works. His many drawings are noted for their luminosity and lively style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Alleine, English minister and author (b. 1611)

entities.title: Richard Alleine
entities.description: Richard Alleine was an English Puritan divine.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Newbery, English publisher (b. 1713)

entities.title: John Newbery
entities.description: John Newbery, considered "The Father of Children's Literature", was an English publisher of books who first made children's literature a sustainable and profitable part of the literary market. He also supported and published the works of Christopher Smart, Oliver Goldsmith and Samuel Johnson. In recognition of his achievements the Newbery Medal was named after him in 1922.

heading: Deaths
txt: Percivall Pott, English physician and surgeon (b. 1714)

entities.title: Percivall Pott
entities.description: Percivall Pott was an English surgeon, one of the founders of orthopaedics, and the first scientist to demonstrate that a cancer may be caused by an environmental carcinogen.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Vernon, English-American merchant (b. 1719)

entities.title: William Vernon
entities.description: William Vernon, of Newport, Rhode Island, was a New England trader who played a leading role in the Continental Congress' maritime activities during the American Revolution. As president of the Eastern Navy Board during the Revolution, he was responsible for building and outfitting the ships of the Continental Navy.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Hyde Wollaston, English chemist and physicist (b. 1766)

entities.title: William Hyde Wollaston
entities.description: William Hyde Wollaston was an English chemist and physicist who is famous for discovering the chemical elements palladium and rhodium. He also developed a way to process platinum ore into malleable ingots.

heading: Deaths
txt: Manuel María Lombardini, Mexican general and politician. President (1853) (b. 1802)

entities.title: Manuel María Lombardini
entities.description: Manuel José María Ignacio Lombardini de la Torre was a Mexican general and politician who supported Antonio López de Santa Anna. From 8 February 1853 to 20 April 1853, he served as president of Mexico.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Victor Poncelet, French mathematician and engineer (b. 1788)

entities.title: Jean-Victor Poncelet
entities.description: Jean-Victor Poncelet was a French engineer and mathematician who served most notably as the Commanding General of the École Polytechnique. He is considered a reviver of projective geometry, and his work Traité des propriétés projectives des figures is considered the first definitive text on the subject since Gérard Desargues' work on it in the 17th century. He later wrote an introduction to it: Ap

heading: Deaths
txt: Gustavo Adolfo Bécquer, Spanish journalist, poet, and playwright (b. 1836)

entities.title: Gustavo Adolfo Bécquer
entities.description: Gustavo Adolfo Claudio Domínguez Bastida, better known as Gustavo Adolfo Bécquer, was a Spanish Romanticist poet and writer, also a playwright, literary columnist, and talented in drawing. Today he is considered one of the most important figures in Spanish literature, and is considered by some as the most read writer after Miguel de Cervantes. He adopted the alias of Bécquer as his brother Valeria

heading: Deaths
txt: George Eliot, English novelist and poet (b. 1819)

entities.title: George Eliot
entities.description: Mary Ann Evans, known by her pen name George Eliot, was an English novelist, poet, journalist, translator and one of the leading writers of the Victorian era. She wrote seven novels, Adam Bede (1859), The Mill on the Floss (1860), Silas Marner (1861), Romola (1862–63), Felix Holt, the Radical (1866), Middlemarch (1871–72) and Daniel Deronda (1876). Like Charles Dickens and Thomas Hardy, she emerge

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul de Lagarde, German biblical scholar and orientalist (b. 1827)

entities.title: Paul de Lagarde
entities.description: Paul Anton de Lagarde was a German biblical scholar and orientalist, sometimes regarded as one of the greatest orientalists of the 19th century. As a conservative political theorist, Lagarde's strong support of anti-Semitism, vocal opposition to Christianity, racial Darwinism and anti-Slavism are viewed as having been among the most influential in supporting the ideology of fascism and Nazism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dwight L. Moody, American evangelist and publisher, founded Moody Publishers (b. 1837)

entities.title: Dwight L. Moody
entities.description: Dwight Lyman Moody, also known as D. L. Moody, was an American evangelist and publisher connected with Keswickianism, who founded the Moody Church, Northfield School and Mount Hermon School in Massachusetts, Moody Bible Institute and Moody Publishers. One of his most famous quotes was “Faith makes all things possible... Love makes all things easy.“ Moody gave up his lucrative boot and shoe busines

entities.title: Moody Publishers
entities.description: Moody Publishers is a nonprofit organization that publishes Christian books, founded in 1894 by Dwight L. Moody.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard von Krafft-Ebing, German-Austrian psychiatrist and author (b. 1840)

entities.title: Richard von Krafft-Ebing
entities.description: Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing was an Austro-German psychiatrist and author of the foundational work Psychopathia Sexualis (1886).

heading: Deaths
txt: Rose Talbot Bullard, American medical doctor and professor (b. 1864)

entities.title: Rose Talbot Bullard
entities.description: Rose Talbot Bullard was an American physician and medical school professor, who was elected president of the Los Angeles County Medical Association in 1902.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frances Xavier Cabrini, Italian-American nun and saint (b. 1850)

entities.title: Frances Xavier Cabrini
entities.description: Frances Xavier Cabrini, also called Mother Cabrini, was an Italian-American Roman Catholic nun. She founded the Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, a Catholic religious institute that was a major support to her fellow Italian immigrants to the United States. She was the first U.S. citizen to be canonized as a saint by the Roman Catholic Church, on July 7, 1946.

heading: Deaths
txt: Aristeidis Moraitinis, Greek lieutenant and pilot (b. 1891)

entities.title: Aristeidis Moraitinis (aviator)
entities.description: Aristeidis Moraitinis DSO was a pioneer Greek military aviator of the early 20th century. During the Balkan Wars (1912–1913) he performed together with Michael Moutoussis the first naval air mission in history, while in the following World War I, he became Greece's only ace with nine aerial victories in total.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hermann Weingärtner, German gymnast (b. 1864)

entities.title: Hermann Weingärtner
entities.description: Hermann Weingärtner was a German gymnast.

heading: Deaths
txt: Amelie Beese, German pilot and engineer (b. 1886)

entities.title: Amelie Beese
entities.description: Amelie Hedwig Boutard-Beese, also known as Melli Beese, was an early German female aviator. She was born in Laubegast, on the outskirts of Dresden, Saxony.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ma Rainey, American singer (b. 1886)

entities.title: Ma Rainey
entities.description: Gertrude "Ma" Rainey was an influential American blues singer and early blues recording artist. Dubbed the "Mother of the Blues", she bridged earlier vaudeville and the authentic expression of southern blues, influencing a generation of blues singers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nathanael West, American author and screenwriter (b. 1903)

entities.title: Nathanael West
entities.description: Nathanael West was an American author and screenwriter. He is remembered for two darkly satirical novels: Miss Lonelyhearts (1933) and The Day of the Locust (1939), set respectively in the newspaper and Hollywood film industries.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karel Hašler, Czech actor, director, composer, and screenwriter (b. 1879)

entities.title: Karel Hašler
entities.description: Karel Hašler was a Czech songwriter, actor, lyricist, film and theatre director, composer, writer, dramatist, screenwriter and cabaretier. He was murdered in the Mauthausen concentration camp.

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Boas, German-American anthropologist and linguist (b. 1858)

entities.title: Franz Boas
entities.description: Franz Uri Boas was a German-born American anthropologist and a pioneer of modern anthropology who has been called the "Father of American Anthropology". His work is associated with the movements known as Historical Particularism and Cultural Relativism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Beatrix Potter, English children's book writer and illustrator (b. 1866)

entities.title: Beatrix Potter
entities.description: Helen Beatrix Potter was an English writer, illustrator, natural scientist and conservationist; she was best known for her children's books featuring animals, such as The Tale of Peter Rabbit.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Langdon, American actor, comedian, and vaudevillian (b. 1884)

entities.title: Harry Langdon
entities.description: Harry Philmore Langdon was an American comedian who appeared in vaudeville, silent films, and talkies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick Freake, English polo player (b. 1876)

entities.title: Frederick Freake
entities.description: Sir Frederick (Charles) Maitland Freake, 3rd Baronet was a British polo player in the 1900 Summer Olympics and in the 1908 Summer Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank George Woollard, English engineer (b. 1883)

entities.title: Frank George Woollard
entities.description: Frank George Woollard, was a British mechanical engineer who worked for nearly three decades in the British motor industry in various roles in design, production, and management. He was a pioneer in what is today called "Lean management," but whose work has been forgotten.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gilda Gray, Polish-American actress and dancer (b. 1901)

entities.title: Gilda Gray
entities.description: Gilda Gray was a Polish-American dancer and actress who popularized a dance called the "shimmy" which became fashionable in 1920s films and theater productions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ninian Comper, Scottish-English architect (b. 1864)

entities.title: Ninian Comper
entities.description: Sir (John) Ninian Comper was a Scottish-born architect. He was one of the last of the great Gothic Revival architects, noted for his churches and their furnishings. He is well known for his stained glass, his use of colour and his subtle integration of Classical and Gothic elements which he described as unity by inclusion.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ross McLarty, Australian politician, 17th Premier of Western Australia (b. 1891)

entities.title: Ross McLarty
entities.description: Sir Duncan Ross McLarty, was an Australian politician and the 17th Premier of Western Australia.

entities.title: Premier of Western Australia
entities.description: The Premier of Western Australia is the head of the executive branch of government in the Australian state of Western Australia. The Premier has similar functions in Western Australia to those performed by the Prime Minister of Australia at the national level, subject to the different Constitutions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Dimbleby, English journalist (b. 1913)

entities.title: Richard Dimbleby
entities.description: Frederick Richard Dimbleby, CBE was an English journalist and broadcaster, who became the BBC's first war correspondent, and then its leading TV news commentator.

heading: Deaths
txt: Raymond Gram Swing, American journalist (b. 1887)

entities.title: Raymond Gram Swing
entities.description: Raymond Gram Swing was an American print and broadcast journalist. He was one of the most influential news commentators of his era, heard by people worldwide as a leading American voice from Britain during World War II. Known originally as Raymond Swing, he adopted his wife's last name in 1919 and became known as Raymond Gram Swing.

heading: Deaths
txt: Enrique Peñaranda, 45th President of Bolivia (b. 1892)

entities.title: Enrique Peñaranda
entities.description: Enrique Peñaranda del Castillo was a Bolivian general who served as the 38th president of Bolivia from 1940 until his overthrow in 1943. He previously served as commander-in-chief of the country's armed forces during the second half of the Chaco War (1932–1935).

entities.title: President of Bolivia
entities.description: The President of Bolivia, officially known as the President of the Plurinational State of Bolivia, is head of state and head of government of Bolivia and the Captain General of the Armed Forces of Bolivia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Godfried Bomans, Dutch journalist and author (b. 1913)

entities.title: Godfried Bomans
entities.description: Godfried Jan Arnold Bomans was a Dutch author and television personality. Much of his work remains untranslated into English.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sterling North, American author and critic (b. 1906)

entities.title: Sterling North
entities.description: Thomas Sterling North, who used Sterling North professionally, was an American writer. He is best known for the children's novel Rascal, a bestseller in 1963.

heading: Deaths
txt: Darryl F. Zanuck, American director and producer (b. 1902)

entities.title: Darryl F. Zanuck
entities.description: Darryl Francis Zanuck was an American film producer and studio executive; he earlier contributed stories for films starting in the silent era. He played a major part in the Hollywood studio system as one of its longest survivors. He earned three Academy Awards as producer for Best Picture during his tenure, but was responsible for many more.

heading: Deaths
txt: D. Boon, American singer and musician (b. 1958)

entities.title: D. Boon
entities.description: Dennes Dale "D." Boon was an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist. Boon was best known as the guitarist and vocalist of the American punk rock trio Minutemen. In 1985 he was killed in a van crash at the age of 27.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Burchell, English author and activist (b. 1904)

entities.title: Mary Burchell
entities.description: Ida Cook was a British campaigner for Jewish refugees and a romance novelist as Mary Burchell.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Penhaligon, Cornish Liberal Politician (b. 1944), MP for Truro (1974-1986)

entities.title: Member of parliament
entities.description: A member of parliament (MP) is the representative of the people who live in their constituency. In many countries with bicameral parliaments, this category includes specifically members of the lower house, as upper houses often have a different title. Member of Congress or Deputy is an equivalent term in other jurisdictions. Another term is Parliamentarian.

entities.title: Truro (UK Parliament constituency)
entities.description: Truro was the name of a parliamentary constituency in Cornwall represented in the House of Commons of England and later of Great Britain from 1295 until 1800, then in the Parliament of the United Kingdom from 1801 to 1918 and finally from 1950 to 1997. Until 1885 it was a parliamentary borough, electing two members of parliament (MPs) by the plurality-at-large system of election; the name was then

heading: Deaths
txt: Luca Prodan, Italian-Scottish singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1953)

entities.title: Luca Prodan
entities.description: Luca Prodan was an Italian-Scottish musician and singer who rose to fame as the leading vocalist of Sumo, one of the most influential rock bands of Argentina, and is widely considered as one of the country's most important artists. He was the older brother of film actor and composer Andrea Prodan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chico Mendes, Brazilian trade union leader and activist (b. 1944)

entities.title: Chico Mendes
entities.description: Francisco Alves Mendes Filho, better known as Chico Mendes 15 December 1944 – 22 December 1988), was a Brazilian rubber tapper, trade union leader and environmentalist. He fought to preserve the Amazon rainforest, and advocated for the human rights of Brazilian peasants and indigenous peoples. He was assassinated by a rancher on 22 December 1988. The Chico Mendes Institute for Conservation of Biod

heading: Deaths
txt: Samuel Beckett, Irish author, poet, and playwright, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1906)

entities.title: Samuel Beckett
entities.description: Samuel Barclay Beckett was an Irish novelist, playwright, short story writer, theatre director, poet, and literary translator. A resident of Paris for most of his adult life, he wrote in both French and English.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Bluestone, English violinist and composer (b. 1907)

entities.title: Harry Bluestone
entities.description: Harry Bluestone was a British violinist who composed music for TV and Movie. He was prolific and worked mainly on composing with Emil Cadkin. Earlier on, he was a violinist and freelanced on radio in the 1930s with Artie Shaw, Benny Goodman and the Dorsey Brothers. Some of his compositions were also featured on APM Music. He retired in 1987 and died of tuberculosis in Studio City, California on De

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick William Franz, American religious leader (b. 1893)

heading: Deaths
txt: Don DeFore, American actor (b. 1913)

entities.title: Don DeFore
entities.description: Donald John DeFore was an American actor. He is best known for his roles in the sitcom The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet from 1952 to 1957 and the sitcom Hazel from 1961 to 1965, the former of which earned him a Primetime Emmy Award nomination.

heading: Deaths
txt: Butterfly McQueen, American actress and dancer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Butterfly McQueen
entities.description:
Butterfly McQueen was an American actress. Originally a dancer, McQueen first appeared in films as Prissy in Gone with the Wind (1939). She was unable to attend the movie's premiere because it was held at a whites-only theater.
Often typecast as a maid, she said: "I didn't mind playing a maid the first time, because I thought that was how you got into the business. But after I did the same thing o

heading: Deaths
txt: James Meade, English economist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1907)

entities.title: Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences
entities.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, officially the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, is an economics prize administered by the Nobel Foundation. While it is not one of the Nobel Prizes, which were established by Alfred Nobel's will in 1895, it is commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Economics. The prize was established in 1968 by a donation fr

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Hamm, American cartoonist and television host (b. 1916)

entities.title: Jack Hamm
entities.description: Jack Beaumont Hamm was an American artist from Wichita, Kansas who is recognized both for his Christian-themed artwork and editorial cartoons, and for his books on drawing technique. He both studied and taught at the Frederic Mizen Academy of Art. As a cartoonist and comic strip letterer, he worked on the Bugs Bunny, Alley Oop, and Boots and Her Buddies comic strips before attending Baylor Univers

heading: Deaths
txt: Sebastian Arcos Bergnes, Cuban-American dentist and activist (b. 1931)

entities.title: Sebastian Arcos Bergnes
entities.description: Sebastian Arcos Bergnes was a Cuban human rights activist. A prominent Cuban dissident, he was openly adversarial to the dictatorships of Fidel Castro and Fulgencio Batista.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ovidiu Iacov, Romanian footballer (b. 1981)

entities.title: Ovidiu Iacov
entities.description: Ovidiu Nicolae Iacov was a Romanian footballer. During his career he played only for Steaua București.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Newton Read, American lawyer and second chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission (b. 1918)

entities.title: New Jersey Casino Control Commission
entities.description: The Casino Control Commission is a New Jersey state governmental agency that was founded in 1977 as the state's Gaming Control Board, responsible under the Casino Control Act for licensing casinos in Atlantic City. The commission also issues licenses for casino key employees and hears appeals from decisions of the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement. The commission is headquartered in the Ar

heading: Deaths
txt: Desmond Hoyte, Guyanese lawyer, politician and President of Guyana (b. 1929)

entities.title: Desmond Hoyte
entities.description: Hugh Desmond Hoyte was a Guyanese politician who served as Prime Minister of Guyana from 1984 to 1985 and President of Guyana from 1985 until 1992.

entities.title: President of Guyana
entities.description: The President of the Co-operative Republic of Guyana is the head of state and the head of government of Guyana, as well as the commander-in-chief of the armed forces of the Republic, according to the Constitution of Guyana. The president is also the chancellor of the Orders of Guyana. Concurrent with their constitutional role as Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, the President does not appoin

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Strummer, English singer-songwriter (b. 1952)

heading: Deaths
txt: Doug Ault, American baseball player and manager (b. 1950)

entities.title: Doug Ault
entities.description: Douglas Reagan Ault was an American professional baseball first baseman and designated hitter who played for the Texas Rangers (1976) and Toronto Blue Jays. He is best known for hitting the first two home runs in Blue Jays history, in the team's first Major League Baseball (MLB) game on April 7, 1977, a 9–5 Toronto win against the Chicago White Sox.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elena Mukhina, Russian gymnast (b. 1960)

entities.title: Elena Mukhina
entities.description: Elena Vyacheslavovna Mukhina was a Soviet gymnast who won the all-around title at the 1978 World Championships in Strasbourg, France. Her career was on the rise and she was widely touted as the next great gymnastics star until 1979 when a broken leg left her out of several competitions, and the recovery from that injury combined with pressure to master a dangerous and difficult tumbling move cause

heading: Deaths
txt: Galina Ustvolskaya, Russian composer (b. 1919)

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Court, Australian politician, 21st Premier of Western Australia (b. 1911)

entities.title: Charles Court
entities.description: Sir Charles Walter Michael Court, was a Western Australian politician, and the 21st Premier of Western Australia from 1974 to 1982. He was a member of the Liberal Party.

entities.title: Premier of Western Australia
entities.description: The Premier of Western Australia is the head of the executive branch of government in the Australian state of Western Australia. The Premier has similar functions in Western Australia to those performed by the Prime Minister of Australia at the national level, subject to the different Constitutions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Adrian Cristobal, Filipino journalist and playwright (b. 1932)

heading: Deaths
txt: Luis Francisco Cuéllar, Colombian rancher and politician (b. 1940)

entities.title: Luis Francisco Cuéllar
entities.description: Luis Francisco Cuéllar Carvajal was a Colombian politician, serving as Mayor of Morelia, Governor of the Caquetá Department from 2008 to 2009, and Deputy Governor of Caqueta from 2000 to 2003. He is known for being kidnapped and murdered by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, and for being kidnapped and held for ransom four times.

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Scanlon, English footballer (b. 1935)

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Foy, American soldier and announcer (b. 1921)

entities.title: Fred Foy
entities.description: Frederick William Foy was an American radio and television announcer and actor, who used Fred Foy as his professional name. He is best known for his narration of The Lone Ranger. Radio historian Jim Harmon described Foy as "the announcer, perhaps the greatest announcer-narrator in the history of radio drama."

heading: Deaths
txt: Chuck Cherundolo, American football player and coach (b. 1916)

entities.title: Chuck Cherundolo
entities.description: Charles James Cherundolo, Jr. was an American football player and coach. He played center and linebacker for ten seasons in the National Football League (NFL) with the Cleveland Rams, Philadelphia Eagles and Pittsburgh Steelers. He was born in Old Forge, Pennsylvania.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ryan Freel, American baseball player (b. 1976)

heading: Deaths
txt: Cliff Osmond, American actor, director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1937)

heading: Deaths
txt: Lim Keng Yaik, Malaysian physician and politician (b. 1939)

heading: Deaths
txt: Diomedes Díaz, Colombian singer-songwriter (b. 1956)

entities.title: Diomedes Díaz
entities.description: Diomedes Díaz Maestre was a Colombian vallenato singer, songwriter, and composer. His nickname, "El Cacique de la Junta", was given to him by another vallenato singer, Rafael Orozco Maestre, to honor Díaz's birthplace.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Hækkerup, Danish lawyer and politician (b. 1945)

heading: Deaths
txt: Oscar Peer, Swiss author, playwright, and philologist (b. 1928)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Robert Beyster, American physicist and academic (b. 1924)

entities.title: John Robert Beyster
entities.description: John Robert Beyster, often styled J. Robert Beyster, was the founder of Science Applications International Corporation. He was Chairman of the Board until his retirement in July 2004, and also served as Chief Executive Officer (CEO) until November 2003. A recognized authority on national security and nuclear reactor physics, Beyster committed 35 years of his life to building SAIC on the founding t

heading: Deaths
txt: Christine Cavanaugh, American actress (b. 1963)

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Cocker, English singer-songwriter (b. 1944)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard Stone, American lawyer and politician (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Lundblad, Swedish singer-songwriter (b. 1950)

entities.title: Peter Lundblad
entities.description: Gustaf Peter Lundblad was a Swedish singer and songwriter, well known for his 1986 song Ta mig till havet. Lundblad started his career in the band 'The most Remarkable Nailband' where Lasse Tennander appeared as songwriter. Later they started the band 'Duga' but Tennander left the band quickly. In 1978, Lundblad and Torbjörn wrote and recorded the song Who Will Comfort Toffle? which also is a chil

heading: Deaths
txt: Freda Meissner-Blau, Australian activist and politician (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: Chad Robinson, Australian rugby league player (b. 1980)

entities.title: Chad Robinson
entities.description: Chad Damian Robinson was an Australian professional rugby league footballer. Robinson spent several years in Australia's National Rugby League with the Parramatta Eels and the Sydney Roosters and a season with Super League side Harlequins RL.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gonzalo Morales Sáurez, Costa Rican painter (b. 1945)

entities.title: Gonzalo Morales Sáurez
entities.description: Gonzalo Morales Sáurez was a Costa Rican painter. He studied in The San Fernando Academy in Madrid, Spain from 1970 to 1974. He is best known for his hyper-realistic works, and has exhibited his art in many museums and art galleries in Europe and the Americas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Simcha Rotem, last survivor of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising (b. 1924)

entities.title: Simcha Rotem
entities.description: Simcha Rotem was a Polish-Israeli veteran, who was a member of the Jewish underground in Warsaw, and served as the head courier of the Jewish Fighting Organization (ŻOB), which planned and executed the Warsaw ghetto uprising against the Nazis. He was one of the last two surviving Jewish fighters in the Warsaw uprising and the last surviving fighter from the 1943 Warsaw ghetto uprising.

entities.title: Warsaw Ghetto Uprising
entities.description: The Warsaw Ghetto Uprising was the 1943 act of Jewish resistance in the Warsaw Ghetto in German-occupied Poland during World War II to oppose Nazi Germany's final effort to transport the remaining ghetto population to Majdanek and Treblinka death camps.

txt: Herman Sikumbang, Indonesian guitarist (b. 1982); casualty during 2018 Sunda Strait tsunami

entities.title: 2018 Sunda Strait tsunami
entities.description: On 22 December 2018, a tsunami that followed an eruption and partial collapse of the Anak Krakatau volcano in the Sunda Strait struck several coastal regions of Banten in Java and Lampung in Sumatra, Indonesia. heading: Deaths
txt: Ram Dass, American spiritual teacher and author (b. 1931)

entities.title: Ram Dass
entities.description: Ram Dass, also known as Baba Ram Dass, was an American spiritual teacher, psychologist, and author. His widely known book, Be Here Now (1971), has been described as "seminal", and helped popularize Eastern spirituality and yoga with the baby boomer generation in the West. heading: Deaths
txt: Leslie West, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1945)

entities.title: Leslie West
entities.description: Leslie West was an American rock guitarist, vocalist, and songwriter. He was best known as a founding member and co-lead vocalist of the hard rock band Mountain.
